 STRUCTURE OF POLYGONAL IMPACT CRATERS AT MERIDIANI PLANUM, MARS, AND A MODEL RELATING TARGET STRUCTURE TO CRATER SHAPE. W. A. Watters, Dept. EAPS, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Bldg 54, Cambridge, MA 02139 (watters@mit.edu)    Introduction:  Among the classic field- and laboratory studies of crater structure, a handful have mentioned the influence of fracture networks upon crater shapes [1,2,3] and few later investigations have addressed the problem directly (see [4] for a recent study and thorough review).  A polygonal simple crater is thought to result when the excavation flow exploits planes-of-weakness in the target, so that fracture sets approximately bisect crater corners.  The straight walls of complex craters are thought to align with regional joints because crater walls collapse along pre-existing fractures.  The ongoing MER mission at Meridiani Planum provides a unique chance to test ideas about the relationship between target structure and crater shape.     Structure of Endurance Crater and fracture networks at Meridiani: Terrain meshes generated from MER NAVCAM and PANCAM stereo pairs were used to measure the strike and dip of bedding planes in the sedimentary rocks exposed in the walls of Endurance Crater.  In this way, we have located the hinge of an overturned flap in the rim walls, and have identified faults with significant scissors-type displacement.  Multi-spectral PANCAM images have been used to map and describe the deformation of layering in the crater walls, as well as the inverted stratigraphy exposed in the rim.  Especially noteworthy is that layers exhibit a festoon shape, suspended between corners of the Endurance polygon (Fig. 1), suggesting possible tear faults where the excavation flow exploited pre-existing fractures. In MOC imagery, the plains of Meridiani Planum appear dissected by fracture-like lineaments (Fig. 2): the "Anatolia" trough system that Opportunity has since visited en route to Endurance crater [5].  We have measured the orientations of these troughs in two MOC cPROTO images in the vicinity of Endurance (MOC cPROTOs R1104449 and R1602188). Both images separately exhibit bimodal distributions, with centers at ~35º and  ~-12º from North. (The illumination angles are orthogonal.)  More recently, Opportunity has encountered a system of fractures measuring up to 20 cm in width (Fig. 2c) and up to ten meters in length.  Using the NAVCAM terrain meshes we have confirmed that a dominant mode of the widest fractures align with the dominant mode of the trough system, suggesting that the troughs correspond to fractures into which the plains sands have drained over time. A Simple Model Relating Fracture Geometry to Crater Shapes: At Meridiani Planum and across the surfaces of heavily cratered terrestrial bodies like the Moon and Mars, polygonal simple craters occur in a wide variety of shapes.  Informal observations in MOC imagery of fracture networks on crater floors and patterned ground in the northern lowlands indicate that, where fracture networks are visible, fractures frequently intersect crater corners.  At Endurance crater, the corners in several cases coincide with major faults.  The walls between corners of simple polygons are sometimes straight, and sometimes rounded -- and often both types occur in the same crater.  With these observations in mind, we can identify the properties that a simple model should exhibit: (a) the corners of crater outlines lie on major fractures;  (b) where there aren't fractures to produce corners, the outline is given by a the limit of excavation flow in a homogeneous target (a circle or circular arc).    As a first attempt to find simple models that can replicate shape distributions, we use the following rules to construct crater outlines: (1) first specify a network of fractures (straight lines) in the plane, a center P of the excavation flow, and an excavation radius R for a homogeneous target; (2) draw a circle of radius R at P; (3) for each line (fracture) at least partially inside the circle, extend the excavation envelope by an amount proportional (by factor α) to the line's length inside the circle measured from the point [along the line] nearest to the center;  (4) obtain the convex hull of all "corner" points and connect the dots;  (5) wherever one of the resulting lines crosses the circle, connect these points  instead by the circular arc that includes a single point on the circle.    If the mean fracture spacing is ∆, then for R ~ ∆ or R slightly greater than ∆ and assuming a simple orthogonal network of fractures, the model reproduces the whole range of shapes seen at Meridiani and elsewhere.  For the same network and R >> ∆, aligned squares (with beveled corners) are generated instead.  For R >> ∆ and a symmetrical pattern of 3 joint directions, the result is aligned hexagons (not uncommon for simple and complex craters alike).  For angular separations of 60 degrees, the resulting sides of the regular hexagon are aligned with the fracture orientations, as observed in the case of many complex craters.  For a given fracture network and crater size distribution and factor α, the model can be used to predict a  distribution of wall segment orientations.  As a preliminary test of the model, we have measured 864 wall orientations for 320 craters in MOC image E0201844, containing a dense field of simple polygons roughly 100 km SE of Endurance crater.  The network assumed in the model consists of two fracture sets, with orientations supplied by the two modes of trough orientations mentioned earlier.  In Fig. 3 we plot a histogram of the orientations along with the model prediction.  The model correctly anticipates two minima and the approximate location of one peak.  Agreement is otherwise poor and the results highly preliminary.  (N.B. trough networks are not clearly visible in the imagery available for this location, and may be more complex than what occurs at Endurance.)     Work is underway to collect a much larger distribution at Meridiani, to measure the population of fracture directions using MER images, and to test simple models like the one proposed here at other locations around Mars.  Also under development is a program that automatically measures crater wall orientations.     If a simple model of this type is ultimately successful, model distributions might be used to learn about the structure of target materials even where factures are not visible to spacecraft.  Since craters of different sizes excavate to different depths, distributions for different size ranges may elucidate the structure of fracture networks or the effective mechanical properties of the crust with depth.  The characterization of fracture networks has many applications, from learning about tectonic history to identifying formation processes and material properties, as well as charting migration pathways for volatiles.
